claim.statement_location: Main text, page 2: 'We found that the mobility decreased on average by 3.4% (95%CI: 3.3%, 3.6%) per day from March 2 through March 26. Social distancing measures decreased the mobility by an additional 23% (95%CI: 20%, 27%).'

data.source: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI); government and media websites for social distancing policy implementation dates
data.sample_size: 1,025 observations across 41 cities (25 observations per city)
data.access_details: CMI publicly available at https://citymapper.com/cmi; policy implementation dates tabulated from official government and media websites
data.notes: CMI is based on planned trips in the Citymapper app and does not include personal automobile navigation; measures classified as moderate or intense based on intensity of closure; findings may not generalize to populations not using public transport.

method.description: The study analyzed Citymapper Mobility Index data for 41 cities from March 2–26, 2020 and tabulated the timing and intensity of governmental social distancing measures. A multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model was used to estimate changes in mobility over time and the additional effect associated with social distancing measures.
steps: Download Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) data for 41 cities from March 2 to March 26, 2020.
Tabulate implementation dates of governmental social distancing measures for each city from official government and media sources.
Classify cities as having instituted social distancing if non-essential businesses were closed; further classify measures as moderate or intense based on closure intensity.
Construct a panel dataset with daily CMI values and policy indicators for each city.
Estimate a multilevel mixed-effects linear regression model to assess the effect of time and social distancing measures on mobility.
Compare mobility trends and evaluate differences by policy intensity (moderate vs intense).
method.outcome_variable: Citymapper Mobility Index (percent of baseline planned trips)
method.independent_variables: Time (days from March 2 to March 26); indicator for presence of social distancing measures; indicator(s) for intensity of measures (moderate vs intense)

results.summary: Mobility declined substantially across the 41 cities. Median mobility fell from 100% on March 2 to 10% by March 26. Modeling showed an average daily decrease of 3.4% in mobility over the study period, and an additional 23% reduction associated with the implementation of social distancing measures. No significant difference was observed between moderate and intense policy classifications.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Additional change in mobility associated with social distancing measures

metadata.original_paper_title: COVID-19 related social distancing measures and reduction in city mobility
